history.content: Read through the first two chapters of Rudin's Principles of Mathematical Analysis; if you don't know Rudin is very terse and skips a lot of details in his arguments. You should be able to fill in every detail on your own and the proofs should make complete sense to you. If this isn't the case then you aren't ready for 104.

children.subject: 104 is nothing like math 53. You’ve likely seen everything (i mean the results) covered in math 104 before actually, besides basic metric space topology (like in AP calc bc or math 1b). However in 104 instead you formalize everything and prove (almost) everything, which is something that took mathematicians hundred years after calculus was invented to develop. So yeah, it can be pretty challenging. Make sure you know how to prove stuff.
At the very least, practice basic direct proofs, proofs by contradiction and contraposition, and induction proofs.

Have you taken math54? If so, you can go onto Math110 first, which the Math department recommends as the first upper division math course you should take before any other Math upper divs, because the transition from lower division style to upper division style is easier, and I felt Math110 really helped build my proof writing skills. 

If you haven't taken 54 or any linear algebra or don't need/care about linear algebra then this isn't the best route but an option!

history.content: I took IB HL math in high school and math 53 first semester freshman year and didn't take them very seriously. What is a good way to prepare for math 104?
history.subject: Prep for Math 104
